No incorrect behavior, crash, or failing test is reported and a maintainer replied that the code is debug-only and not used in production. This is an enhancement/suggestion about defensive coding (CWE-252), not a confirmed bug in hyperscan, so I classify it as not a real bug."
}

  "log": null,
  "summary": "This issue is a style/question about whether to use double quotes or angle brackets for #include in hs.h, not a report of incorrect behavior, crash, or performance/memory problem. Project maintainers explained that double quotes are intentional to prefer headers from the same directory/version, so this is a design choice and not a bug. Therefore it does not qualify as a real bug per the classification criteria." 
}

  "log": "**recipe for target 'src/parser/Parser.cpp' failed**",
  "summary": "The issue reports that the CMake script does not check for the presence of the ragel package, causing builds to fail with the make error shown. This is a genuine build-system bug (missing dependency check) and was fixed according to the comment referencing commit ba0b2b7. I classify the discovery method as manual (user ran make and observed the failure). The provided fix pointer is the commit hash cited in the comments."
}

  "log": null,
  "summary": "This is a usage question/misunderstanding, not a bug. The reporter expected pcapscan to handle TCP reassembly and gzip/HTTP decoding; the maintainer clarified Hyperscan is only a regex engine and pcapscan is a minimal example that does not perform reassembly or decompression. Therefore the absence of matches is due to missing preprocessing in the caller, not a defect in Hyperscan." 
}

{
  "number": "11",

  "fixed_pointer": [],
  "bug_kind": null,
  "how_found": null,
  "reproduction_pattern_and_input": [],
  "log": null,
  "summary": "The report describes unexpected SOM_LEFTMOST behavior when using HS_FLAG_DOTALL with a pattern containing .*?; a maintainer explains this is expected due to Hyperscan's automata semantics (it reports all possible matches and leftmost start is 0) rather than a backtracking engine difference. The issue is a user misunderstanding of semantics, not a defect in Hyperscan. The maintainer also suggests an alternative approach (splitting into separate start/end patterns) to achieve the desired extraction."
}

  "log": null,
  "summary": "This issue is a user question asking where Visual Studio solution/project files are located. The maintainer replied that Hyperscan uses CMake to generate VS solutions and that project files are not kept under source control. This is a request/usage question and not a report of incorrect behavior, crash, or other defect, so it does not qualify as a real bug."
}

}

  "log": null,
  "summary": "This is a usage/question issue asking about the difference between libhs.so and libhs_runtime.so. The maintainers answered that libhs_runtime is a smaller C-only runtime for scanning (no compile APIs) and pointed to serialization/deserialization APIs; the reporter confirmed no further questions. There is no reported incorrect behavior, crash, or other defect, so this does not represent a real bug." 
}

{
  "number": "17",
  "is_real_bug": false,
  "is_fixed": false,
  "found_pointer": [],
  "fixed_pointer": [],
  "bug_kind": null,
  "how_found": null,
  "reproduction_pattern_and_input": [],
  "log": null,
  "summary": "This issue is a feature-question asking whether Hyperscan will support full PCRE capturing-group semantics (as in the Chimera project). The maintainers replied that Chimera was a separate hybrid approach and full capturing semantics are not planned for Hyperscan due to incompatibility with its streaming model; an alternative prefiltering approach was suggested. No incorrect behavior, crash, or defect is reported or confirmed, so this is not a bug but a feature/query and can be closed."
}

{
  "number": "20",
  "is_real_bug": false,
  "is_fixed": false,
  "found_pointer": [],
  "fixed_pointer": [],
  "bug_kind": null,
  "how_found": null,
  "reproduction_pattern_and_input": [],
  "log": null,
  "summary": "The report describes a crash (SIGILL) when a Hyperscan-built library compiled on a Haswell machine (with AVX2/BMI2) is run on an older Ivy Bridge CPU that lacks those extensions. Discussion in the thread confirms the cause is compilation with CPU-specific instruction set flags (e.g., -march=native or -mavx2) rather than a defect in Hyperscan itself; the appropriate resolution is to compile for the target CPU or use the fat-runtime support introduced later. This is a misconfiguration/portability issue, not an engine bug, so I classify it as not a real bug."
}

{
  "number": "25",
  "is_real_bug": false,
  "is_fixed": false,
  "found_pointer": [],
  "fixed_pointer": [],
  "bug_kind": null,
  "how_found": null,
  "reproduction_pattern_and_input": [],
  "log": null,
  "summary": "The report notes that patterns like '(^|.)' and '($|.)' can match the empty string but do not trigger Hyperscan's \"Pattern matches empty buffer\" compilation error. Project maintainers replied that this is expected: the engine only detects simple empty-match patterns and does not attempt the more complex analysis needed to warn on the broader class of patterns that also match empty strings. This is therefore a limitation/feature gap (missing static analysis), not a confirmed engine crash, memory error, or incorrect matching behavior; no fix or specific failing version/commit/log was provided."
}

  "log": null,
  "summary": "The reporter expected hs_expression_info() to enforce the same compile-time constraints as hs_compile(), but maintainers explained this is a misunderstanding: hs_expression_info()/hs_expression_ext_info() are meant to provide information about an expression, not to act as a lightweight compiler. Flags like HS_FLAG_ALLOWEMPTY do not change the expression's semantics and so hs_expression_info() may succeed while hs_compile() fails for implementability or resource reasons. The maintainer updated documentation to clarify this, so the report does not describe a bug in the engine."
}

  "summary": "The issue reports a build failure on CentOS el5u7 when building hyperscan-4.5.1: mktemp on that old distro does not support the --tmpdir option used by cmake/build_wrapper.sh, causing make to fail. This is a genuine build-script portability bug (not a runtime or regex bug). The report includes the failing build log and the exact file/line implicated (cmake/build_wrapper.sh:14); maintainers discussed a fix (change mktemp invocation) but no fix commit or release pointer is provided, so is_fixed is false. I classified how_found as MANUAL_REVIEW because the failure was observed while manually running the build."
}

  "summary": "The report shows that a pattern compiled in UTF8 mode (/(*UTF8)x.{73}/) fails with “Pattern is too large” while the ASCII-mode pattern (/x.{32000}/) succeeds. Project maintainers explained this is due to '.' in UTF8 covering a very large set of code points (≈1,112,064), causing an enormous NFA and a compile-size limit. This is an expected limitation/implementation constraint rather than a correctness crash or semantic bug, and no fix or manifest bug was reported — the issue is effectively a usage/limitation discussion, not a confirmed engine bug."
}

  "summary": "This issue is a question about whether NUL (\\0) bytes can appear in regex patterns. The comments explain that the primary compile APIs take C-style NUL-terminated strings (use strlen()) so an embedded NUL ends the pattern, while the literal-compile APIs accept an explicit length and thus can contain NUL bytes. A maintainer suggests using the escape \"\\x00\" in regular APIs. This is an API limitation/expected behavior rather than a crash, incorrect matching, or confirmed defect, so it does not qualify as a real bug."
}

  "summary": "The issue reports real crashes when a Hyperscan serialized database is mmapped/moved: internal runtime structures require 64-byte alignment, but deserialization can insert padding assuming a different base alignment, leading to misaligned internal headers and VMOVDQA instructions touching unaligned addresses and crashing. This is a genuine bug (crash caused by incorrect handling of alignment when databases are moved/mmap'ed). The discovery was via user reports and manual inspection of cores and assembler traces; a workaround was applied in rspamd (commit 068714f...), but Hyperscan itself has not been fixed in this issue. I classified it as CRASH and included the referenced hyperscan commit hash and the rspamd fix commit hash, plus the exact assembler and structure dump excerpts from the discussion."

",
  "summary": "The reporter changed all -march flags to -march=core2 and, although the project built, many unit tests fail with API calls returning -6 instead of expected success codes. This is a reproducible runtime failure observed on two different modern machines and with gcc 11.4.0, so it represents a real defect in behavior when building with -march=core2. I classify this as a SEMANTIC bug because the library's API returns incorrect error codes/behavior at runtime after the altered build flags. No fix or commit is mentioned in the issue."
}
